word.description: As in English, {橙} denotes both the [fruit](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Orange_(fruit)) and the [color](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Orange_(colour).

images.place: Wendy's Noodle Cafe, Las Vegas, Nevada

description: As in English, {橙} denotes both the [fruit](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Orange_(fruit)) and the [color](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Orange_(colour).

word.description: {蔗} is [sugarcane](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sugarcane), and {汁} is *juice*, so {蔗汁} is [sugarcane juice](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sugarcane_juice).

description: [Sugarcane juice](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sugarcane_juice) is a (very sugary) liquid made from pressed [sugarcane](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sugarcane).

word.description: Apple [cider](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cider) is known in Cantonese by a loanword {西打} pronounced sāi dá, and in Mandarin by a more literal {蘋果酒]} ({蘋果} is *apple*, and {酒} is *alcohol*, so 蘋果酒 is *apple alcohol*).

The glyph origins of {水} resemble a flowing stream. {氵} is the left radical form of this character, so if you see a character with that on the left, chances are it has something to do with water or liquid, e.g. {酒} *liquor*, {油} *oil* (the edible kind) or *sauce*, {海} *ocean*, and {清} *soup*.

**Ordering**

{杯} is *cup* (or mug or glass) and is the [measure word](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Measure_word) for water (and other drinks), and {一} is *one*, so to order a glass of water, ask for 一杯水 (yāt būi séui in Cantonese, yī bēi shuǐ in Mandarin), *one cup of water*.

images.place: Sweet Honey Dessert, Las Vegas, Nevada

word.description:
{冰} is *ice*, and {水} is *water*, so {冰水} is *ice water*.

**Ordering**

{杯} is *cup* (or mug or glass) and is the [measure word](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Measure_word) for water (and other drinks), and {一} is *one*, so to order a glass of ice water, ask for 一杯冰水 (yāt būi bīng séui in Cantonese, yī bēi bīng shuǐ in Mandarin), *one cup of ice water*.
